metadata.title: Diffusion Tensor Imaging in Presymptomatic and Early Huntingtons Disease: Selective White Matter Pathology and Its Relationship to Clinical Measures
metadata.abstract: Atrophy of cortical and subcortical gray matter is apparent in Huntingtons disease (HD) before symptoms manifest. We hypothesized that the white matter (WM) connecting cortical and subcortical regions must also be affected early and that select clinical symptoms were related to systems degeneration. We used diffusion tensor magnetic resonance imaging (DTI) to examine the regional nature of WM abnormalities in early HD, including the preclinical period, and to determine whether regional changes correlated with clinical features. We studied individuals in early stages (HD), presymptomatic individuals known to carry the genetic mutation that causes HD (Pre-HD), and matched healthy controls. DTI indices of tissue integrity were obtained from several regions of interest, including the corpus callosum (CC), internal capsule (IC), and basal ganglia, were compared across groups by t tests, and were correlated to cognitive and clinical measures. WM alterations were found throughout the CC, in the anterior and posterior limbs of the IC, and in frontal subcortical WM in HD subjects, supporting the selective involvement of the pyramidal tracts in HD; a similar distribution of changes was seen in Pre-HD subjects, supporting presymptomatic alterations. There was a significant relationship between select DTI measures and cognitive performance. Alterations in diffusion indices were also seen in the striatum that were independent of atrophy. Our findings support that WM alterations occur very early in HD. The distribution of the changes suggests that these changes contribute to the disruption of pyramidal and extrapyramidal circuits and also support a role of compromised cortical circuitry in early cognitive and subtle motor impairment during the preclinical stages of HD.

Untitled Section 1.text:
Huntingtons disease (HD) is a devastating neurological disorder caused by the abnormal repeating expansion of a trinucleotide sequence in the coding region of the IT15 gene on chromosome 4. 1 The disease is characterized clinically by involuntary movements, psychiatric disturbances, and cognitive decline. Neuropathologic studies show selective degeneration of vulnerable populations of neurons with a predilection for degeneration of the striatum. 2 Recent studies suggest that brain degeneration extends well beyond the striatum in HD, involving both cortical and subcortical brain regions. Involvement of the cerebral cortex has been of particular interest because huntingtin protein aggregates concentrate in cortical neurons 2,3 more so than in the striatum. The cerebral cortex atrophies in early HD. 4,5 Additionally, cortical alterations have been hypothesized to contribute to striatal degeneration through dysregulation of glutamate and neurotrophin containing afferent projections. Subcortical white matter (WM) degeneration is apparent in advanced HD, 6,7 but the timing of its development and regional patterns have not been characterized, especially in early stages of disease.
Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is an emerging magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) method that has been used to measure alterations in tissue composition in a variety of neurological diseases. Quantitative DTI measures, such as fractional anisotropy (FA) and the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC), provide information about WM integrity 8 but have also been used to examine tissue fiber architecture within gray matter. 9 The DTI signals are indices of brain water diffusion; the biophysical basis of diffusion measures include underlying fiber architecture, fiber density, uniformity of nerve fiber direction, 9 and axonal membranes and cytoskeleton. 8 Because such tissue features are disrupted in pathology studies of neurological diseases, DTI measures are gaining currency in measuring these pathologic changes in life. For example, DTI has detected altered diffusion measures in WM regions appearing normal on conventional MRI scans in subjects with multiple sclerosis 10 and alcoholism. 11 We used the microstructural sensitivity of DTI to examine brain tissue alterations in presymptomatic (Pre-HD) and symptomatic HD. We hypothesized (1) that the anatomy of WM degeneration would correspond to fiber bundles associated with regions of accelerated gray matter atrophy 4,10 -14 ; (2) that tissue changes would be present early, before the onset of motor symptoms; and (3) that tissue measures would be associated with specific clinical measures in patients with HD. We used complementary data analysis approaches, with hypothesis-based region of interest (ROI) analyses providing manual, individualized measures of tissue integrity, and whole brain voxel-based maps allowing for exploratory analyses of regions not hypothesized to show tissue changes in HD. We examined whether WM degeneration occurs early in the disease process by studying a group of early symptomatic individuals as well as a group of individuals known to carry the gene for HD but who were asymptomatic.

Subjects.text: HD (n ϭ 17) and Pre-HD (n ϭ 15) subjects were recruited from the Massachusetts General Hospital (MGH) Movement Disorders Clinic, and control subjects (n ϭ 29) were recruited from the community. All HD subjects had unequivocal motor symptoms and a known family history of HD. All Pre-HD subjects carried a trinucleotide repeat expansion and did not have motor symptoms of HD. All subjects were assessed by a neurologist from the Movement Disorders Clinic at MGH (H.D.R. or S.M.H.). Subjects with a history of alcohol or drug abuse within the previous year or taking medications or experimental agents that could mask motor symptoms were excluded. Procedures were fully explained to all subjects and written informed consent was obtained before scanning. Protocols were performed in compliance with institutional guidelines provided by the internal review board at MGH. All subjects were assessed with cognitive and functional components of the Unified Huntingtons Disease Rating Scale (UHDRS). Additional assessments of the HD and Pre-HD groups included a motor evaluation. Cognitive assessment included standardized neuropsychological tests, including Verbal Fluency, Symbol Digit Modalities, and Stroop Color Word test. The total functional capacity (TFC) score is a measure of a patients capacity in functional realms, including employability, ability to manage finances, domestic responsibilities, and self-care. TFC scores range from 13 (full capacity) to 0 (total incapacity); this metric is sensitive to early changes in disability. 15 All subjects with HD were in early stages of disease (Stages I, corresponding to a TFC Ն 11, or Stage II, corresponding to TFC values of 8 to 10 16 ) and were living independently. Pre-HD subjects included in this study had a score of at most a 1 confidence rating; a score of 0 indicates a normal examination, 1 indicates minor soft neurological signs that are considered nonspecific.

MRI Acquisition.text: Whole-head high-resolution DTI scans were obtained on a 1.5 T Siemens Sonata MRI scanner (Erlangen, Germany) as described previously. 21 HD and HD control subjects were scanned using the following parameters: TR ϭ 14.4 seconds, TE ϭ 81 msec, in-plane resolution 2 mm ϫ 2 mm, slice thickness ϭ 2 mm (for 2 mm 3 isotropic voxels), 60 slices total, acquisition matrix ϭ 128 ϫ 128, FOV ϭ 256 mm ϫ 256 mm, 6 averages, 6 non-colinear directions with b value ϭ 700 smm 2 , and one image, the T2-weighted low b image with a b-value ϭ 0 smm 2 as an anatomical reference volume. The effective diffusion gradient was  ϭ 37 msec and the bandwidth was 1445 Hzpixel. Images were collected as oblique axial along the plane of the anterior-posterior commissure. Due to a software upgrade, diffusion scan parameters differed only in the TR ϭ 9 msec and 8 averages for the comparison of Pre-HD and Pre-HD control subjects. The difference between the scan sequences would only be expected to increase the signal to noise ratio in the Pre-HD analyses; however, given that even slight differences in scan protocols could affect results, all statistical comparisons were performed only between groups scanned with identical scan parameters. The 2 mm 3 voxel resolution achieved was useful to minimize partial volume contamination among gray matter, white matter, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), compared to standard clinical scans often described in the literature. The DTI acquisitions used a twice-refocused balanced echo, developed to significantly reduce eddy current distortions. 17 Two high-resolution T1-weighted scans (TE ϭ 3.0 msec; TR ϭ 7.25 msec; flip angle, 7 degrees; field of view, 256; matrix, 256 ϫ 192; 1.3 mm sagittal acquisition; NEX ϭ 1) were acquired on all subjects.

Image Processing.text: All data processing was performed using tools developed at the Martinos Center as well as those available through the Freesurfer (http:surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu) and FSL processing streams. 18,19 Data were first motion-and eddy current distortion-corrected using motion correction and registration software in the FSL software suite. The diffusion tensor was calculated for each voxel in the volume using least-squares fit techniques as reported previously. Mean diffusivity and FA were calculated as described in previous publications. 20 To reduce the influence of the CSF, voxels with trace value of above 0.006 (0.6 m 2 sec) were set to 0 and were excluded from subsequent analyses. T1-weighted scans were motion corrected, averaged to enhance the gray-towhite contrast to noise, and smoothed using an iterative nearest neighbor averaging procedure as described previously. 21 Volume of white matter and basal ganglia structures were determined as previously described. 22

Anatomical Localization of ROIs.text:
ROIs were defined on each individuals spatially normalized low diffusion weighting T2 anatomical volume. Use of the spatially normalized low diffusion volume allowed for more consistent placement of ROIs without confounding this placement by differentially distorted scan acquisition. All ROIs were placed by the same rater (N.H.) using a standardized placement procedure that used atlas based reference maps with morphological landmarks. ROIs were created with the intent of sampling FA within a homogenous fiber population, and regional designations were supported by superimposed tensor information.
ROIs were placed in each individuals T2 scan in the genu, body, and splenium of the corpus callosum (CC) and in the anterior and posterior limbs and the genu of the internal capsule. CC ROIs were defined on the mid-sagittal slice and internal capsule ROIs were defined in the axial plane. We additionally placed ROIs in the caudate, putamen, and the pallidum, defined on a coronal slice 8 mm posterior to the anterior commissure. It is important to note that, although DTI studies have focused the measurement technique of WM integrity, a number of studies have used FA as a more generic measure of tissue integrity, and the contrast provided by FA is not technically limited to WM. ROIs in the IC and CC were a sphere with a radius of 3 mm, for a total volume of 33 mm 3 ; because of the significant atrophy of the basal ganglia, ROIs in these basal ganglia structures were 12 mm 3 . This procedure allowed us to avoid arbitrary sizes of ROIs across subjects. Measure of tissue integrity and the contrast provided by FA is not technically limited to WM. To assess the Intrarater reliability, ROIs were placed by the same rater in 12 subjects from each group twice; the intraclass correlation coefficient ranged from 0.87 to 0.97, demonstrating excellent intrarater reliability. Regional values were obtained from the FA maps.

Exploratory Whole-Brain Analysis.text: As a supplementary analysis, we examined the pathologic effects of HD using voxel-based statistical comparisons. FA and ADC maps were first registered to a T2-weighted brain template provided with SPM and then smoothed with a Gaussian kernel of 2 mm full width half maximum. ADC maps were calculated as one third of the trace, or sum of the diagonal elements of the tensor. Comparisons of FA and ADC were computed by t test at each voxel, respectively. Zero-value voxels (e.g., CSF) were excluded from all statistical results to minimize the possible influence of misregistration.

Group Demographics.text: Characteristics of the study groups are presented in Table 1. There were no significant differences between groups with respect to age, years of education, or gender balance. UHDRS subscores were significantly different between HD and control groups. The likelihood of onset for each individual subject in the Pre-HD group was estimated using a parametric survival model based on CAG repeat number, as described recently. 23 Mean values for the group in 5-year intervals are given in Table 2; in our group of subjects, the likelihood of onset within a 5-year period is approximately 17, suggesting that our subjects are still relatively far from estimated onset.

Corpus Callosum.text: We hypothesized that the CC would demonstrate regional changes in HD, reflecting the apparent regional specificity of cortical changes we have reported previously. As shown in Figure 1, there were significant reductions in FA in HD compared to matched control subjects in the genu, body, and splenium. Pre-HD subjects had significantly reduced FA in the body of the CC compared to matched control subjects.

Internal Capsule.text: Regional differences in FA were also seen in the IC, as shown in Figure 2. There were unexpected increases in FA in the anterior limb, bilaterally, and left genu, as well as significant decreases in FA in the posterior limb, bilaterally, in the HD group compared to matched controls. Significant increases in FA were seen bilaterally in the anterior limb and significant decreases in FA were seen bilaterally in the posterior limb in the Pre-HD group compared to controls.

Basal Ganglia.text: Significant increases in FA were seen in the putamen and globus pallidus, bilaterally, in the HD group compared to matched controls, and bilaterally in the putamen in Pre-HD, as shown in Figure 3. There was no significant difference in FA of the caudate in Pre-HD or HD subjects.

Whole Brain Voxel-Based Analyses.text: Results of the voxel-based t test comparisons are presented in Figure 4 and Table 3. These analyses were consistent with the results from the ROI analyses, demonstrating significant alterations in FA in both Pre-HD The likelihood of onset for each individual in the Pre-HD group (Huntingtons disease gene-positive, without motor symptoms) was calculated using a parametric survival model and the mean probabilities are given. For our group, the likelihood of onset occurring within 5 years is approximately 17, suggesting that the subjects in our study were reasonably far from onset.

FIG. 1. Fractional anisotropy (FA) of th.text: . FA values were obtained from individually placed regions of interest in three distinct regions of the CC known to project to distinct areas of cortex. In early stage Huntingtons disease (HD) subjects, FA of the corpus callosum was significantly reduced in the genu, body, and splenium compared to age, sex, and sequence-matched controls. In presymptomatic individuals known to carry the genetic mutation that causes HD (Pre-HD), FA of the body was significantly reduced compared to matched controls. P Ͻ 0.05;  P Ͻ 0.005. and HD subjects. In the Pre-HD group, increases in FA were present in the putamen and decreases were present in the posterior limb of the internal capsule as well as subgyral frontal WM and WM underlying sensorimotor cortex, and thalamus, primarily pulvinar. In the HD group, increases in FA were seen in the putamen and globus pallidus and decreases were seen in the IC, CC, externalextreme capsules, cerebral peduncles, brainstem, thalamus, and WM underlying deep frontal, sensorimotor, parietal, and parieto-occipital brain regions. The findings of similar, yet more extensive changes in FA in the HD group maps compared to the Pre-HD group maps suggests that the findings are both reliable and that the alterations in FA likely are progressive.

Apparent Diffusion Coefficient.text: Prior studies have suggested that measures of apparent diffusion are less sensitive to tissue changes than FA, yet could provide unique information. Increases in ADC has been reported in other neurodegenerative diseases. Whole-brain ADC values were significantly increased in the HD subjects compared to controls (P Ͻ 0.05), but not in Pre-HD subjects compared to controls. Voxel-based maps demonstrated significant increases in ADC values in the putamen and globus pallidus in HD (P Ͻ 0.0001) and Pre-HD subjects (P Ͻ 0.005; not shown) compared to respective controls. As our procedures used a mask for regions in which there was high contamination of CSF, a separate ROI analysis was performed for the caudate; there was no significant difference between groups in the ADC of the caudate.

White Matter and Basal Ganglia Volumes.text: WM volumes were not significantly different in the Pre-HD group compared to controls (reduced by 2.5; P ϭ 0.8), but were reduced by 14 in the HD group (P Ͻ 0.01). Volumes of the caudate, putamen, and globus pallidus were reduced in both Pre-HD and HD subjects (HD: caudate 50, putamen 42, globus pallidus 25; Pre-HD: caudate 25, putamen 18, globus pallidus 7). There was no relationship between striatal volumes and FA, for any of the structures, in the HD or Pre-HD groups, compared to respective controls (not shown).

Correlational Analyses.text: Pearsons correlations were calculated to measure the association between ROI FA values and clinical measures of the UDHRS as shown in Figure 5. In HD subjects, FA values from the genu and body of the CC were statistically correlated with performance on the Stroop Color Word interference task. In Pre-HD subjects, FA values from the body of the CC were statistically correlated with performance on the Stroop Color Word Interference task. There was no significant correlation seen in this study between FA of the caudate, putamen, or globus pallidus with cognitive scores or with TFC. Similarly, there was no relationship between FA and volume of the caudate, putamen, or globus pallidus.

DISCUSSION.text:
The prevailing model of HD views the clinical symptoms as resulting from abnormal functioning of basalganglia-thalamo-cortical circuitry, 24 originating largely from striatal degeneration. Our results demonstrate that corticocortical and corticofugal WM abnormalities also occur in HD and that such changes are correlated with clinical and cognitive measures. Furthermore, the changes are also in place before the onset of clinical symptoms. Thus, together with our previous findings of early and progressive cortical thinning, 4 the current data suggest that the clinical expression of HD is also a result of abnormalities in distinct white matter tracts. WM volume loss has been reported previously in neuroimaging studies of symptomatic HD 10,25 and in postmortem studies, but it has been unclear whether these changes occur globally or are more regionally restricted. Given our previous findings of regionally selective thinning of the cortex in both symptomatic and in presymptomatic subjects, we hypothesized that selective alterations would also be present in WM regions that were functionally associated with cortical areas that we have reported previously as thinned in HD and in Pre-HD. By extension, this finding suggested also that only those regions of a WM bundle that were functionally correlated to these specific cortical areas would demonstrate alterations in FA and similarly that other regions would be unchanged. We also hypothesized that these alterations played an important role in some of the clinical symptoms of HD. Finally, as recent reports have suggested that even gray matter structures have intrinsic FA values and, as the striatum is known to be severely affected in HD, we also studied the caudate, putamen, and globus pallidus.
In our study, we found that alterations in the microstructural integrity of select regions of interest, as measured by FA, were indeed present. In the internal capsule, decreases in FA were found in the posterior limb of the internal capsule. The exploratory analyses supported this finding and also suggested alterations in posterior frontal WM and the cerebral peduncles, constituents of the corticospinal pathway, in both HD and Pre-HD subjects. Our previous findings of significant thinning in the sensorimotor cortex further supports our hypothesis that the brain is affected in a nonrandom manner and suggests that brain regions that subserve similar functions may be affected in parallel. Parenthetically, the primary motor cortex has been found to have large numbers of huntingtin aggregates, 26 and early involvement of this pathway may explain the hyper-reflexia that is found early in disease.
The CC has received little attention in HD, but it is the major source of commissural information transfer in the

FIG. 4. Diffusion tensor fractional anis.text:
(FA) group statistical maps. Exploratory wholebrain analyses demonstrated significant reductions in FA in the internal capsule (IC), frontal subcortical white matter (WM), and portions of the thalamus, and increases in FA in the putamen in the group of presymptomatic individuals known to carry the genetic mutation that causes Huntingtons disease (Pre-HD; upper panel), paralleling the results of the region of interest analysis. In the early stage Huntingtons disease (HD) group, significant increases in the putamen and globus pallidus were seen; reductions in FA included the IC, corpus callosum (CC), external extreme capsule, cerebral peduncles, brainstem, and WM underlying brain regions, including sensorimotor cortex, frontal, parietal, and parieto-occipital areas. Blue areas show areas of statistically significant increases in FA; yellow areas show areas of statistically significant reductions in FA.
brain. It is one of the most heavily myelinated regions of the brains and is topographically organized longitudinally from genu to splenium. 27 Considering this organization, and in light of our findings of thinning involving posterior frontal regions in presymptomatic subjects, 21 we also hypothesized that regional changes in the CC would correspond to regional cortical atrophy. In Pre-HD subjects, changes in FA were present selectively in the body of the CC. As expected, in HD subjects, FA changes were more widespread, presumably related to more widespread atrophy in the symptomatic stages of the disease. Consonant with our observations, others have reported deficits in presymptomatic subjects in cognitive tasks requiring executive function and nonspatial working memory, 28 -31 tasks that require commissural transfer between cortical dorsolateral prefrontal and partietal cortex, for example. An important role for these regional alterations of the corpus callosum in the symptoms of HD is supported by the finding of relationships between regional FA and clinical variables. We found a significant correlation between performance on the Stoop and verbal fluency and FA of the genu and body. This finding suggests that alterations in the corpus callosum are important and may reflect the pathological changes in the cerebral cortex.
It is still not clear what reductions in FA mean with respect to specific neuropathological changes in the HD brain. Reductions in FA may be caused by several processes, including a decrease in the number or density of axons, diminished myelination of axons, or decreased orientational coherence of the fiber tracts. Microstructural changes in WM may have been predicted by previous work in which huntingtin aggregates, 32333435 altered axonal morphology, 36 -39 and slowed axoplasmic transport 40 have been demonstrated in axons from brains of patients with HD. The selective vulnerability of specific WM components, such as those that make up corticos-triatal pathways, is consistent with previous neuroimaging studies 25 that have demonstrated significant atrophy of white matter and in neuropathological studies that have shown early degeneration of these pathways in HD. 13,40 In our study, unexpected increases in both FA and diffusivity, as measured by ADC, were found in the putamen and globus pallidus, in both Pre-HD and HD subjects. Increases in ADC values for the striatum have been shown previously, 41 but FA measures in HD have not been reported previously. In our study, caudate FA and ADC values were not significantly different. In general, FA and diffusivity are negatively correlated. 39 The divergence of this typical pattern in the basal ganglia in our study suggests a unique pathology in these structures in early HD that is distinct from atrophy. We speculate that increases in FA could result from pathologic processes that modify tissue integrity, such as neuronal remodeling and loss and secondary astrocytosis, loss of specific fiber tracts, changes in fiber composition, or changes in cell permeability; however, the biophysical basis of pathologic alterations in FA is currently unknown. The caudate, putamen, and globus pallidus are known to have fibrillary astrocytosis in HD, and neuronal remodeling within the striatum has been demonstrated in postmortem studies of HD. 42 Importantly, tissue changes were apparent in Pre-HD subjects in the absence of significant WM volume loss, suggesting that subtle morphological alterations occur before the development of overt motor symptoms. The concordance of the regional changes in Pre-HD and HD subjects in both this study supports the validity of the findings and suggests that WM degeneration is a progressive phenomenon with advancing disease; however, this conclusion needs to be confirmed in a longitudinal study. Our work provides evidence of early and progressive pyramidal and extrapyramidal motor systems degeneration that parallels the cortical thinning of sensorimotor regions in HD. Whether the WM changes reflect a primary degeneration, such as demyelination, or occur secondary to cortical gray matter degeneration remains to be elucidated. Nevertheless, our findings suggest that alterations in cortical neurons and their connectivity likely contribute to the early clinical symptoms that occur in HD. Whereas motor slowing and hyper-reflexia become evident in the middle stages of disease as obvious cortical signs, early cognitive and subtle motor impairment during the preclinical stages of disease are also likely to have some basis in compromised cortical circuitry.
